Speaker: NARRATOR
Text: AND thus, Glaucon, after the argument has gone a weary way, the true and the false philosophers have at length appeared in view.

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: I do not think, he said, that the way could have been shortened.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: I suppose not, I said; and yet I believe that we might have had a better view of both of them if the discussion could have been confined to this one subject and if there were not many other questions awaiting us, which he who desires to see in what respect the life of the just differs from that of the unjust must consider.

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: And what is the next question? he asked.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Surely, I said, the one which follows next in order.  Inasmuch as philosophers only are able to grasp the eternal and unchangeable, and those who wander in the region of the many and variable are not philosophers, I must ask you which of the two classes should be the rulers of our State?

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: And how can we rightly answer that question?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Whichever of the two are best able to guard the laws and institutions of our State--let them be our guardians.

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: Very good.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Neither, I said, can there be any question that the guardian who is to keep anything should have eyes rather than no eyes?

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: There can be no question of that.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And are not those who are verily and indeed wanting in the knowledge of the true being of each thing, and who have in their souls no clear pattern, and are unable as with a painter's eye to look at the absolute truth and to that original to repair, and having perfect vision of the other world to order the laws about beauty, goodness, justice in this, if not already ordered, and to guard and preserve the order of them--are not such persons, I ask, simply blind?

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: Truly, he replied, they are much in that condition.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And shall they be our guardians when there are others who, besides being their equals in experience and falling short of them in no particular of virtue, also know the very truth of each thing?

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: There can be no reason, he said, for rejecting those who have this greatest of all great qualities; they must always have the first place unless they fail in some other respect.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Suppose then, I said, that we determine how far they can unite this and the other excellences.

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: By all means.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: In the first place, as we began by observing, the nature of the philosopher has to be ascertained.  We must come to an understanding about him, and, when we have done so, then, if I am not mistaken, we shall also acknowledge that such an union of qualities is possible, and that those in whom they are united, and those only, should be rulers in the State.

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: What do you mean?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Let us suppose that philosophical minds always love knowledge of a sort which shows them the eternal nature not varying from generation and corruption.

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: Agreed.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And further, I said, let us agree that they are lovers of all true being; there is no part whether greater or less, or more or less honourable, which they are willing to renounce; as we said before of the lover and the man of ambition.

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And if they are to be what we were describing, is there not another quality which they should also possess?

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: What quality?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Truthfulness:  they will never intentionally receive into their mind falsehood, which is their detestation, and they will love the truth.

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: Yes, that may be safely affirmed of them.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: 'May be,' my friend, I replied, is not the word; say rather 'must be affirmed:'  for he whose nature is amorous of anything cannot help loving all that belongs or is akin to the object of his affections.

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: Right, he said.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And is there anything more akin to wisdom than truth?

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: How can there be?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Can the same nature be a lover of wisdom and a lover of falsehood?

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: Never.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: The true lover of learning then must from his earliest youth, as far as in him lies, desire all truth?

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: Assuredly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: But then again, as we know by experience, he whose desires are strong in one direction will have them weaker in others; they will be like a stream which has been drawn off into another channel.

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: He whose desires are drawn towards knowledge in every form will be absorbed in the pleasures of the soul, and will hardly feel bodily pleasure--I mean, if he be a true philosopher and not a sham one.

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: That is most certain.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Such an one is sure to be temperate and the reverse of covetous; for the motives which make another man desirous of having and spending, have no place in his character.

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: Very true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Another criterion of the philosophical nature has also to be considered.

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: What is that?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: There should be no secret corner of illiberality; nothing can more antagonistic than meanness to a soul which is ever longing after the whole of things both divine and human.

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: Most true, he replied.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Then how can he who has magnificence of mind and is the spectator of all time and all existence, think much of human life?

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: He cannot.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Or can such an one account death fearful?

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: No indeed.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Then the cowardly and mean nature has no part in true philosophy?

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: Certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Or again:  can he who is harmoniously constituted, who is not covetous or mean, or a boaster, or a coward-can he, I say, ever be unjust or hard in his dealings?

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: Impossible.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Then you will soon observe whether a man is just and gentle, or rude and unsociable; these are the signs which distinguish even in youth the philosophical nature from the unphilosophical.

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: There is another point which should be remarked.

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: What point?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Whether he has or has not a pleasure in learning; for no one will love that which gives him pain, and in which after much toil he makes little progress.

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: Certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And again, if he is forgetful and retains nothing of what he learns, will he not be an empty vessel?

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: That is certain.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Labouring in vain, he must end in hating himself and his fruitless occupation?

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Then a soul which forgets cannot be ranked among genuine philosophic natures; we must insist that the philosopher should have a good memory?

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And once more, the inharmonious and unseemly nature can only tend to disproportion?

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: Undoubtedly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And do you consider truth to be akin to proportion or to disproportion?

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: To proportion.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Then, besides other qualities, we must try to find a naturally well-proportioned and gracious mind, which will move spontaneously towards the true being of everything.

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Well, and do not all these qualities, which we have been enumerating, go together, and are they not, in a manner, necessary to a soul, which is to have a full and perfect participation of being?

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: They are absolutely necessary, he replied.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And must not that be a blameless study which he only can pursue who has the gift of a good memory, and is quick to learn,--noble, gracious, the friend of truth, justice, courage, temperance, who are his kindred?

Speaker: GLAUCON
Text: The god of jealousy himself, he said, could find no fault with such a study.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And to men like him, I said, when perfected by years and education, and to these only you will entrust the State.
